body: @piiswrong Hmm... I see, this is indeed a problem....although in that way the conv operator will end up having (recursively) attributes like `weight_lr_mult`, `weight_weight_lr_mult`, `bias_weight_lr_mult`, etc.

@antinucleon We might need to update amalgamation includes to reflect latest changes in the code
OK. Will check it

You are probably missing some dlls in your PATH environment.
I solved the problem I had by using 
`C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\bin\dumpbin.exe` 
to check which dependent dll is missing.

@pluskid Another way @piiswrong proposed is: use negative number for original dim, eg

```
dshape = (64, 3, 7, 7) # start from 1 to n
oshape = reshape(dshape, (-1, 0, -2, 7)) # 0 means infer,  positive means new dim, negative means original dim
# oshape = (64, 7, 3, 7)
```

I think in this way it is same to lasagne's way in functional, but in a new syntax. How do you like this way?

Thanks I will look

Respectfully,
Andrew Weir

@antinucleon Could be an option, but this could be confusing. Especially Python counts from 0, yet `-1` means the 0-th dimension. It adds confusion when other languages counting from 1 is involved. I am starting to wondering in what scenario do we need to refer to the i-th original dimension. If this is rarely used, we might just go with the current implementation?

ok, let's merge current way.

Hi @lyttonhao , thank you so much for your help, Now I am able to training on my dataset.
Thank you!
You may consider your problem as a multi-label one and prepare the training data by following #1404

@EasonD3  
Hi, thanks a lot for your kind reply. However, I think multi-label option in MXNet is made for fixed number of labels for the example [here](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/io.html#parameters-for-data-iterator):  

`integer_image_index \t label_1 \t label_2 \t label_3 \t label_4 \t path_to_image`

However, my problem here is that the number of tags for each image is not the same.

@piiswrong @tqchen It seems when passing `path_imglist`, all of the labels will be loaded once (according to [`ImageLabelMap`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc#L35) in `ImageRecordIter`). In this case, for OP's problem (_with 8600 labels_), the RAM consumption is gonna be huge, if PO is using millions of training examples.

Better to consider using a data iter for labels?

@Xiaoming-Zhao you can simply use a lengthy binary vector to represent the labels/tags of each image. In this case, the label vector of each image will be of size 4. As a result, A's label will be [1, 1, 1, 0], and B's [0, 1, 0, 1].
you can write a simple dataiter to wrap around the two
This is intentional. Deconv layers usually don't have a bias
Rebased. I believe this is ready for review?
Is the workspace for deconvolution and convolution reported as part of the `total allocated`?
@vchuravy Thank you. The new CustomOp is exactly what I want.

@tqchen @antinucleon @winstywang @piiswrong due to the change #2109 , the newest mxnet will fail when build, and **all the recently pull request failed** is the same reason, so it seems that in lru.cu needs use `--use_fast_math` to build.
@tornadomeet Which CUDA version are you using? I am using CUDA 8.0 and 7.5, both works well.
@antinucleon  here is CUDA-7.0, it shoud be the cuda version.

The problem is caused by old nvcc segfault when expanding template. As LRN is not widely used, I think currently we can ignore it.
Compiling is fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2135

looks good to me
you do not need to separate the label into multi part, for the ioiter supports label_width(=2 here), so you can just input your original label.
currently, ImageRecordIter only support one input dataiter, so you should write your own dataiter and put the data in one list, you'd better do it in the python side for simple.
Please see pr #2136 for the new doc.

Hi @tornadomeet 

I refer to multi-task sample exists in mxnet samples folder.

``` python

class Multi_mnist_iterator(mx.io.DataIter):
    '''multi label mnist iterator'''

    def __init__(self, data_iter):
        super(Multi_mnist_iterator, self).__init__()
        self.data_iter = data_iter
        self.batch_size = self.data_iter.batch_size

    @property
    def provide_data(self):
        return self.data_iter.provide_data

    @property
    def provide_label(self):
        provide_label = self.data_iter.provide_label[0]
        # Different labels should be used here for actual application
        return [('softmax1_label', (self.batch_size,)), \
                ('softmax2_label', (self.batch_size,))]

    def hard_reset(self):
        self.data_iter.hard_reset()

    def reset(self):
        self.data_iter.reset()

    def next(self):
        batch = self.data_iter.next()
        print batch.label[0].asnumpy()
        return mx.io.DataBatch(data=batch.data, label=[label, label], \
                pad=batch.pad, index=batch.index)
```

Hi,

I think the .txt file should work also.
try following command 

```
~/mxnet/bin/im2rec  train.txt  /media/data/ train.rec resize=32
~/mxnet/bin/im2rec  val.txt    /media//data/ vali.rec  resize=32
```

which /media/data/ is the base folder of your dataset  resize=32 means the input shape of your images
for base folder , ex
assume you have two folder under /media/data/ named category1, category2, then in the train.txt should looks like
0 labelforcategory1 category1/00001.jpg
1 labelforcategory2 category2/00001.jpg
....
use relative path instead of full path here if you specify basefolder.

good luck!

Err...

Thanks anyway!!
no, they are not so far. These are dynamic memory that are allocated in the first pass

what I mean input shape is for the network, you don't need to generate mean data mxnet will generate it if not exists.I don't think mxnet will subtract mean automarically, you need do it mannually.
Okay, when it will generate mean data? The time I generate .rec file? or at the beginning during training stage?
at the beginning of training。

So, what about when I applied my trained network to predict a new input image. Will it subtract the mean data automatically? I do not have mean data... (Maybe at the beginning of training, mxnet generates the mean data and stores it physically?
you need manually subtract mean. mxnet generate mean data at the begining of teaining.

So, that's the problem. After I finished my training, and I got my trained network, but no mean data(if mxnet did not save the automatically-generated mean data at the beginning of training), I am not quite sure about how to subtract mean manually... sad...
do you specify mean option to your dataiter?
ah, could you be a bit  more specific...

`train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = args.data_dir + "_train.rec",
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        batch_size  = args.batch_size,
        rand_crop   = True,
        rand_mirror = False,
        num_parts   = kv.num_workers,
        part_index  = kv.rank)

```

    path_imgrec = args.data_dir + "_val.rec",

    part_index  = kv.rank)`
```

train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = os.path.join(args.data_dir, args.train_dataset),
        mean_r      = 123.68,
        mean_g      = 116.779,
        mean_b      = 103.939,

        batch_size  = args.batch_size,

        rand_mirror = True,
        num_parts   = kv.num_workers,
        part_index  = kv.rank)
by default , it use fixed value, replace mean_r,g,b to mean=os.path.join(args.data_dir, "mean.bin")

sorry i reply you through mobilephone, i can't say more detailed.
specify such option, and mxnet will generate mean.bin for you. have a try.
Oh, thank you!  Appreciate!!
ping: @antinucleon

@piiswrong This counts every output of a node once, so this should still work for LSTMs? But I haven't looked at one of them to see how their memory structure is.

In general something like this is quite useful, I was just experimenting with a very deep network and the memory usage for gradients and outputs was dominating the memory cost for everything else.
@piiswrong Sure. See #2143
@jermainewang can you review this?

Thanks for the PR, please also update https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md to add yourself to the list of contributors. 

Thanks for making mxnet better for the community!
Thanks! This looks great, let us add link to it in the system/index.md as well as how_to/new_op.md and we can merge it in
Did not come up with a better solution. I changed `/` back to `_`. Let us get this merged for now.

@piiswrong: is this CustomOp API compatible with other languages, like R via Rcpp? In the previous API, the custom forward and backward function pointers in NativeOpInfo could be given state via a void\* argument. This is no longer the case. What was the motivation for dropping this? (perhaps I'm missing something)
@sbodenstein They can be added. Usually the people using julia or R does this since python doesn't need it.
mx.sym.YOURSYMBOL(attr={'lr_mult': 0.01})
Thanks, I will try.
we should change these to using keyword argument
Let's try if travis works after rebase to the latest master.
@piiswrong Do you mean to make it similar to numpy like `sum(axis=..)`?
It should be attr={'lr_mult': '0.01'}
lets also put this under what's new. BTW do we have a example using keyword argument? like sum(axis=1)

Question: loss in mxnet seems to have a convention that only the gradient is given. e.g. we don't have mean cross entropy loss value from SoftmaxOutput, or mean squared error from LinearRegressionOutput. They seem to be implemented in mxnet.metric. In the example of smooth l1 loss, I did calculate the loss itself as well as the gradient. Do we need to factor smooth l1 loss to  that convention? And should it be documented in the guide?

We should have both: direct output for simple loss and sumed loss value for composition.
Because it doesn't make sense to composite outputs.
This should be carefully documented though.
summed loss value layers can have a additional output for output maybe
Really looking forward to some updates.
@mli is probably busy lately. Can someone takeover this?

That's right. We can composite linear regression from mx.sym.square(in - out). Then it is a direct output for simple loss. With modifications to `mx.sym.MakeLoss` we can sum loss value and output directly. Existing `mx.sym.LinearRegressionOutput` can cope with `mx.metric` for summed loss value. I think it would be appropriate to leave this documentation in the operator description instead of a developer guide. I will modify `MakeLoss` for this behavior in next pr.

As for the keyword arguments, I am so sure how to use that appropriately and need an example myself. And where is `what's new`?
Anyway I think this doc is ready for now. Maybe we should fix minor details later.

I am facing the same problem. Does anyone have solutions right now? 
Thank you very much!!!
It would be great if we can refactor sum with the axis support. But since this PR is an improvement of existing API. We can merge it in for now after verifying its correctness.
You need to first convert them to uint8
